3.0	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no incidents with off-site impacts involving a regulated substance as defined in the regulation at the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant in the past five years. 

3.1 Recordkeeping and Reporting

All accidents and incidents which results in death, injury, or tangible physical effects to the facility, surrounding vicinity, or environment are recorded and reported to the appropriate administering agencies.  Records are maintained for a minimum period of five (5) years from the date of the incident. 
 
3.2 Incident Investigation

FM O&G has an incident investigation program which requires the investigation of each incident that resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in, release of a regulated substance.  Recommendations and corrective action identified during the investigation of incidents are tracked and then implemented as required. 
4.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Despite the best planning incidents can still occur.  It is essential that emergency pre-planning and training make employees aware of, and able to execute, proper actions.  For this reason, an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the entire facility has been developed and implemented in accordance with the provisions of other OSHA rules (8 CCR 3220).  In addition, the emergency action plan includes procedures for handling small releases.

2.7 Seismic Summary

Seismic safety concerns for this facility have been mitigated by early planning studies and conservative design specifications for the facility.  The geological settings of this facility were reviewed extensively by the previous owner of this facility and the County of Santa Barbara during the environmental impact review.  This information was used to design the process structures of the facilities.  Based on this information, conservatism was integrated into the civil and seismic design criteria beyond Uniform Building Code.  These criteria and specific engineering drawings were approved by a third-party professional engineer for the Santa Barbara County Building Department.

The review and approval of building permits for the design and construction of the facility provides reasonable assurance that the release of any regulated substance having offsite consequences will not occur because of an earthquake.  The seismic design criteria, coupled with the mechanical and building codes, and a comprehensive and rigorous equipment testing, and inspection program are primary mitigations to seismic and other external events.

 1.6 Emergency Response Program Summary

FM O&G developed written emergency response procedures to address all elements that may be encountered during planning, response, or follow-up of an emergency at the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant.  These emergency response procedures address releases of regulated substances, including the possibility of fires or explosions.  The procedures address the following issues:  1) various aspects of proper emergency first-aid and medical treatment for exposures; 2) notification of local emergency response agencies; 3) evacuation plans for the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant and methods of accounting for facility personnel after an evacuation; and 4) post-incident cleanup/decontamination requirements.  In addition, the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant follows procedures that address the maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment and alarms. 

Application of the emergency response procedures ensures compliance with the Cal-OSHA Standard 8 CCR 3220 (Emergency Action Plans).  The basic concept of these emergency procedures is to provide a comprehensive approach for managing emergencies.  The four elements of this approach are prevention, preparedness, response, and recovery.

1.4	Summary of Offsite Consequence Analysis Results
1.4.1 Worse-Case Release Scenario

The worst-case release for flammables, as defined in the regulation, is a release of flammable materials resulting in a vapor cloud explosion of the maximum inventory of the largest vessel.  Even though the normal operating inventory for this equipment is often less than the maximum capacity, and this equipment is protected by high level alarms/shutdowns, pressure relief valves, periodic inspections, and routine monitoring by operating personnel, this maximum inventory must be assumed to be released in 10 minutes and ignited at the point of release.

The worse-case release scenario modeled for the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant is a release of the entire volume of the flammable material stored in one of two butane/propane 30,000 gallon storage vessels.  The Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant has a total of three 30,000-gallon vessels located in the southeast corner of the facility, two butane/propane storage vessels as stated above and one vessel containing natural gas liquids.  Per 40CFR68.25(b)(1), the greatest amount held in a single vessel shall be used to determine the worst-case release quantity.   The worse-case release scenario did not identify any off-site impacts and no impact to public, environmental, and residential receptors.  

1.4.2 Flammable Alternative Release Scenario

The alternative release scenario for flammables is a release of a flammable mixture which results in a vapor cloud fire.  The alternative release scenario identified no off-site impact.

The nearest public road is Harris Grade Road, approximately 0.25 miles to the west.  The facility is relatively remote and bounded by undeveloped private property.  The facility is fenced in, and access is controlled by a locked gate that is manned 24 hours a day.  A map of the area is shown in Figure 2-1.

The Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant is a relatively small industrial operation, occupying approximately 20 acres and consisting of one Program 1 process. The Gas Plant qualifies for Program 1 based on the criteria in Section 2735.4 of Title 19 of CCR, the distance to the specified endpoint for the worst-case accidental release scenario is less than the distance to the nearest public receptor. Within the past five years, the process has had no accidental release that caused offsite impacts provided in the risk management program Section 2735.4 (c)(1). No additional measures are necessary to prevent offsite impacts from accidental releases.

The facility receives incoming crude oil and gas from an offshore platform (including some gas from the adjacent onshore oilfield operated by Sentinel Peak Resources) and then utilizes several operations to produce natural gas and natural gas liquids for product.  The incoming oil is processed in the oil treating portion of the facility where water and other contaminates are separated from the crude oil before it is shipped via pipeline to a refinery for further processing.  The incoming gas is treated by removing water, hydrogen sulfide, and other heavy hydrocarbon components.  The hydrocarbon liquids which are separated out are sent to pressure vessels for storage before being trucked offsite to distributors.  The dry natural gas from the process is sold as a product.

1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.1	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Freeport-McMoRan Oil & Gas (FM O&G) is the owner and operator of the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant.  It is the policy of FM O&G that its employees, environment, property, and the general public be protected from any off-site impacts that may occur as a result of its operations.  To achieve this end, FM O&G strives to operate its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations. FM O&G has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety at the Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention (e.g., personnel training, safety consideration in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility, etc.).  The company's philosophy is to implement reasonable mitigation measures to eliminate preventable releases of regulated substances as well as non-regulated substances. 
  
The Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant activates its emergency response policies to comply with the overall FM O&G policy of providing its workers with a safe workplace and of minimizing risk to the public. The safety of emergency and non-affected personnel is the highest priority; therefore, all procedures must be implemented in the appropriate manner (e.g., safely executed rescue and medical activities).  Protection of the environment is also a high priority.  Once the issues of life, safety, and the environment are addressed, the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery may be considered.

Unified Command will be established with Santa Barbara County Fire Department Oil and Gas Supervisor.  Additional resources will be requested as needed to accommodate the needs of the incident. 

1.2	Facility Description

The Lompoc Oil and Gas Plant is located approximately 12 miles inland from the Pacific Ocean and approximately 1.5 miles northeast of Vandenberg Village.
